results.title: [Douglas Wilson Home Movies: Reel 5]
results.brief_description:
Douglas Wilson (1919–1980) was an amateur filmmaker whose films are a snapshot of Australia in the 1950s to 1960s. Douglas’s home movies captured aspects of life in Australia’s major cities as well as in regional areas, often with a focus on public areas, transport or infrastructure projects. A collection of his films has been donated to ACMI by a member of Douglas’s family.

The first part of this film briefly shows an outdoor art show before moving on to water ski jumping on the Yarra River – both are part of the ‘Moomba’ celebrations. The second part shows a road trip from Glenroy to Macedon ending at ‘Cameron Lodge’, Macedon all in Victoria.

Good views of the water ski jumping and the crowds watching from the banks. The road trip shows excellent views of small towns such as Keilor and Diggers Rest, vehicles passing on country roads and roadside scenes including telegraph poles.

Extensive views of the gardens of Cameron Lodge in Macedon including the rotunda, lake, stepping stones and family scenes in the garden.

Originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:00:00 outdoor art show
00:00:44:00 Yarra River
00:01:00:00 the ‘Moomba’ festival on the riverbank
00:01:14:00 water skiing
00:02:00:00 water skiing over a jump
00:02:30:00 crowd watching from riverbank
00:03:40:00 title card ‘Glenroy to Macedon 4-3-61’
00:03:47:00 footage of car trip filmed from moving car showing country roads
00:04:38:00 car parked next to Keilor road sign. Good views of cars on road including VW beetle and Holdens, views of telegraph poles
00:05:05:00 road bridge with curved arch
00:05:10:00 ‘Keilor Hotel’ and parked cars, street scenes
00:05:20:00 Diggers Rest town scenes
00:05:40:00 countryside from moving car
00:06:35:00 Jacksons Creek bridge
00:07:28:00 small town with parked Holdens and BP service station
00:07:46:00 title card ‘Cameron Lodge Macedon 4-3-61’
00:07:52:00 views of Cameron Lodge and man walking in gardens
00:08:24:00 views of garden rotunda
00:08:37:00 two women and baby in lodge garden
00:08:40:00 man photographing garden
00:08:47:00 man in rotunda surrounded by lake, crossing stepping stones
00:09:21:00 group walk through lush vegetation including tree ferns
00:09:46:00 walking through lodge garden
00:10:03:00 children playing in rotunda and on stepping stones
00:10:46:00 group of children and adults on lakeside steps
00:11:10:00 title card ‘The End’

results.title: [Douglas Wilson Home Movies: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
Douglas Wilson (1919–1980) was an amateur filmmaker whose films are a snapshot of Australia in the 1950s to 1960s. Douglas’s home movies captured aspects of life in Australia’s major cities as well as in regional areas, often with a focus on public areas, transport or infrastructure projects. A collection of his films has been donated to ACMI by a member of Douglas’s family.

This film titled ‘Sydney’, contains scenes around the Sydney Harbour and the Sydney Harbour Bridge, including the toll station, Circular Quay, the streets and traffic of the CBD and Toronga Park Zoo.

There are scenes are filmed from a high vantage point, probably the Bridge itself and from a boat or ferry on the Harbour.

Originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:05:00 title ‘Sydney’
00:00:45:00 toll stations on the Sydney Harbour Bridge
00:00:57:00 Circular Quay, yachts and scenes around the Harbour from a high vantage point
00:02:11:00 title card ‘Sydney’ followed by scenes of the city
00:03:25:00 Toronga Park and the zoo
00:03:30:00 pelicans on the water followed by koalas, monkeys, seals, penguins, hippopotamus and giraffe standing by a height chart
00:05:29:00 zebras, antlers, flamingoes, tortoises and an emu, lions and tigers, dingoes or dogs of some kind and deer
00:07:48:00 title card ‘Departure from Sydney’ followed by views around Sydney Harbour

results.title: [Douglas Wilson Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
Douglas Wilson (1919–1980) was an amateur filmmaker whose films are a snapshot of Australia in the 1950s to 1960s. Douglas’s home movies captured aspects of life in Australia’s major cities as well as in regional areas, often with a focus on public areas, transport or infrastructure projects. A collection of his films has been donated to ACMI by a member of Douglas’s family.

This film is mostly focused on the Snowy Mountains Scheme in New South Wales, an integrated water and hydro-electric power utility constructed between 1949 and 1974, located in Australia’s Southern Alps.

There are also some scenes of travel around Brisbane in Queensland.

Frequent title cards assist the viewer with detail, particularly regarding the workings of the hydro Scheme.

Originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:10:00 title ‘Snowy Mountain Scheme 1957’
00:00:22:00 the Snowy Mountain Authority buildings
00:00:44:00 title card ‘Guthega Dam’ followed by views of the dam
00:01:45:00 views of the accommodation buildings
00:02:00:00 title card ‘Guthega Power Station’
00:02:14:00 several views of a large cement pipeline
00:02:55:00 title card ‘Island Bend’
00:03:11:00 a four wheel drive vehicle at the site
00:03:19:00 a Pioneer Express bus waiting for passengers
00:03:22:00 sign ‘Snowy Mountain Lookout’ followed by wide vistas of the mountains
00:03:44:00 title card ‘Adaminaby Dam’
00:04:03:00 trucks working in a quarry and the clearance of trees for the workings of the Scheme
00:04:50:00 workers atop a tower construction
00:05:15:00 sign for the contractors, ‘Etudes Et Enterprises’ at the T.I. power station
00:05:31:00 title card ‘Tumut Ponds’
00:05:48:00 mouths of tunnels into the mountainsides
00:06:27:00 title card ‘Cabramurra’
00:07:41:00 title card ‘Cooma Airport’
00:07:45:00 airplane for Butler Air Transport
00:08:14:00 title card ‘Queensland 1957’
00:08:19:00 Brisbane City Hall
00:08:50:00 title card ‘Mt Coot-Tha’
00:09:14:00 title card ‘Brisbane River’, followed by views of the river
00:09:55:00 ‘Koalas at Lone Pine’ followed by a koala sitting on a dog’s back, and kangaroos
00:10:35:00 ‘Glasshouse Mountains’
00:11:00:00 ‘Long Island’ and a map of the coast of Queensland showing the location
00:11:20:00 beach scenes and an open four wheel drive modified to take passengers from small boats to the shore and on to the holiday huts
00:12:24:00 fishing scenes and wooden boxes full of fish
00:12:40:00 title card ‘Visit to South Molle’
00:13:57:00 title card ‘Visit to Happy Bay’ followed by views around the beach and bay area
00:16:08:00 title card ‘Departure of Guests’ and the holiday visitors are taken on the modified jeep to a small boat, bound for the ferry

results.title: [Alexander Sinclair Home Movies: Reel 13]
results.headline_credit: Australia and Papua New Guinea, c. 1970s
results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This is a very short film, featuring graduating students posing with certificates from Goroka Technical College, Margot Gillian, Chapel and opening of the Development Bank at Goroka.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)
00:01:07:00 opening of Development Bank, Goroka
00:01:43:00 local group perform ceremony in traditional dress to celebrate opening of bank
00:02:11:00 amazing mouth pieces worn by First Peoples as part of their ceremonial dress, procession

results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This film captures a wedding in Goroka, featuring Evelyn Sinclair and friends. The happy couple take off in an airplane for their honeymoon. Relates to reel B2003518.

results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This film is shot in New Guinea and features the filmmaker’s family and friends, locals, people gathering in vast numbers for celebrations in various traditional dress, Chinese dragon display, scenic views, and road safety issues. Most likely filmed around Goroka, as the filmmaker lived mainly in Goroka.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)
00:00:00:00 opens with footage shot around the filmmaker’s home; we see a sign with his name, Alex Sinclair, out the front of the white house; family and friends around the garden
00:03:23:00 car wreck being towed away and off the road
00:04:50:00 filmmaker and friends have a picnic on top of a hill. Local kids come to watch and pose for the camera.
00:05:55:00 along a river, feeding fish with friends, and a nearby wild bird sanctuary or zoo
00:07:29:00 Missionary Aviation Fellowship aircraft at airfield
00:08:32:00 stunning mountain views
00:10:14:00 lunch with friends at a restaurant near the bay
00:11:24:00 traditional Chinese Dragon dance and fire crackers along a town street
00:12:35:00 Lions Club road safety campaign displaying cars salvaged from crashes
00:13:46:00 celebrations of people in traditional dress from various districts; remarkable head dresses and masks made from mud or clay, alongside those made from feathers and woven materials, dancing, building hut demonstrations
00:14:36:00 more truck accidents; local kids come to see, then dance and entertain the filmmaker and friends
00:15:46:00 more stunning views of mountains
00:16:14:00 more ceremonial gatherings of various people and audiences

results.title: [Alexander Sinclair Home Movies: Reel 2]
results.headline_credit: Australia, Netherlands, Switzerland and Wales, c. 1970s
results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This film depicts a trip to the Netherlands and Switzerland, beginning in Welshpool, Wales. It features scenes of “The Dingle” gardens, country fairs, folk dancing, show jumping in Welshpool, Dutch seaside, canal trips in the Netherlands, streetscapes, countryside, farm life, Rotterdam, Spannenburg, bus trip to the Alps, Switzerland, Brienz and Grindenwald.

00:20:58:00 steam train

results.title: [Alexander Sinclair Home Movies: Reel 6]
results.headline_credit: Australia, Hong Kong, Japan, Singapore and Thailand, c. 1970s
results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This film captures a trip to Southeast Asia including Hong Kong, Japan, possibly Thailand and Singapore, including cruising around bays, along rivers, scenic views, traditional dance, temple visits and a visit to Kranji War Cemetery, Singapore.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)
00:00:34:00 Australian Naval Ship in the bay, most likely Hong Kong
00:01:13:00 young boys in small wooden boats appear to be almost knocked over by the ferry or cruise ship the filmmaker is on
00:03:57:00 Shining Star Ferry in Hong Kong
00:04:51:00 plane to Japan
00:07:05:00 a trip to a waterfall, filmmaker’s wife and friends with Japanese friend or tour guide
00:07:53:00 scenic views of possibly Osaka
00:09:17:00 train station, possibly Kansai Station; we see a Kansai Paints billboard behind train
00:10:09:00 a visit to temples surrounded by cherry blossom, perhaps in Kyoto
00:11:10:00 ice skating perhaps in a function centre, skaters dressed in Scottish dress, then Russian, then cowboys
00:13:08:00 possibly views from an airport, a carpark surrounded by mountains, possibly Thailand, as short street views have writing in what appears to be Thai
00:13:35:00 a cruise along a river, markets of people selling food and people living in small houses along the river surrounded by forest and jungle
00:15:40:00 traditional dancers performing and elephant performing tasks for an audience
00:17:05:00 more traditional dancing
00:17:42:00 we see a sign for Kanji War Cemetery, Singapore, a short trip to the memorial
00:18:30:00 snake charmers in a city mall
00:19:22:00 feeding monkeys in a park
00:20:17:00 exotic planet and orchid display
00:21:04:00 possibly back in Australia; a car and boat parade with some of the cars flying the Australian flag

results.title: [Alexander Sinclair Home Movies: Reel 5]
results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This film shows a trip to Israel including visits to Jerusalem before the wall was constructed and various religious sites, such as the Wailing Wall, King David’s Tomb, Lazarus Tomb.

Selected HIghlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)
00:00:52:00 the Wailing Wall, Jerusalem, also known as the Buraq Wall in Islamic
00:01:01:00 Mount of Olives, Chapel of Assencion
00:03:20:00 King David’s Tomb
00:04:25:00 Manger Square
00:09:17:00 local children with animals and tents
00:09:39:00 Beth’ Shearim Catacombs outside the entrance
00:09:59:00 Megiddo City, featuring the city water system, swimming pool
00:10:59:00 Belvouir Castle remains from 12th Century
00:12:22:00 Rosh Hanikra cable car alongside chalk cliffs overlooking the Mediterranean Sea
00:14:42:00 Capharaum – the Town of Jesus, city and scenic views
00:15:36:00 border crossing, family and friends posing with Israel military
00:16:51:00 waterfalls
00:017:05:00 the Good Fence and Temple of Augustus
00:18:34:00 houses in side of mountains
00:19:47:00 high country, stone houses in amongst stone hills with incredible sunsets
00:20:32:00 Lazarus Tomb and Inn of the Good Samaritan
